pros: Friendly co workers and managers, flexible and understanding.
cons: None that I have experienced

pros: Many of the staff from the LRGHealthcare days are dedicated, hardworking, and provide compassionate, high quality care. Concord Hospital has been upgrading some of the pharmacy technology that was lacking at LRGHealthcare Laconia & Franklin campuses due to their financial status.
cons: What was once a very progressive pharmacy department for clinical practice has been rolled back significantly to a more traditional/dispensing model. Going above and beyond in professional development or precepting students is not valued or supported by management. The parent organization is driven by the bottom line. No cross-campus integration makes Laconia/Franklin "second-tier". Laconia has lost many service lines over the years (closure of vascular surgery, maternity, pediatrics, oncology, and bariatric surgery) and now has very limited orthopedic procedures leading to much less variety and lower acuity patients than 4-5 years ago. Franklin also closed their OR suite and ICU, and is now mostly SNF patients plus a small inpatient psychiatry unit.

job_title: Registered Nurse, BSN in Concord, NH
pros: Supportive coworkers, teamwork, and fair benefits - including their pension program, which you have to wait a year to be able to buy into.
cons: Inability to really move up and grow within the company and asking for a raise outside of your yearly review is not taken into consideration. Underwhelmed and disappointed when presenting interest in looking for opportunities and was advised of some recommendations, but not gauranteed it would come with a pay increase.

pros: • Night shift is a whole family. We have each other’s backs and I have always been proud of that. • Pay is pretty decent. Starting at $18.00 but most start at $20.00. Night Diff is $5.00 and 3-11 is $3.00. • Great Equipment is provided: New Tasers, Belts, Cuffs, a whole Security Operations Center, and a state of the art radio system. Brand New Security Vehicle. If we need something they do provide. • Training is alright. The new training manager does a solid job on making sure that people have the resources that they need. • Earned time is very good! 400 Hours a year and if you need a day off, management will approve! • Support staff are awesome. Amanda and Sue are the best and they are not nearly paid enough for what they have to do!
cons: • If you were former Law Enforcement/Corrections you are good until you mess up. If you ever carried a badge on the street the expectation is that you will come in and think like a cop. If you never did, the expectation is that you stay your course and do the grunt work. • Management is “Micromanagement” One Manager is good, the other manager is an equivalent to a dictator. If it’s not in policy its wrong. Management does an amazing job at Monday morning quarterbacking and deciding how you should be doing things, just from reviewing camera footage. If they don’t have a correct answer on something, then they tell you to do it a certain way, you do it that way and they say it was wrong. • Refuse to acknowledge the culture problem. The managers to the director refuse to acknowledge the massive culture problem in the department that has gotten worse. From hiring a Managers wife for dispatch, to ignoring Officer’s and Lead Officer’s concerns, to allowing Medical staff to make decisions on behalf of safety and security. The department as a whole in the last year has lost some great officer’s and the leaders think it’s because there are better opportunities out there not because the culture has gotten so bad! • The department is run like a small Police Department. The director is a Democratic former Police Chief, and all three managers are former Police Officers. For example, a crash on campus is investigated by Concord Police. They come and take a report, but then Security Officers write a report. EVERYTHING IS DOCUMENTED. EVERYTHING IS A REPORT. If you got out of Police Work to stop writing reports, this will not be the place for you! • You will get hurt! This is not a sit down, watch camera’s type of job. You respond to all types of calls including running into dangerous situations with sometimes only 2-3 Officers. When you arrive you have to take direction from Medical Staff even if they don’t know what to do, or if the situation has nothing to do with a medical issue. Many Officers are getting hurt, concussed, and banged up because they are running low on staff and patients are becoming more violent. • The Behavioral Health Department is a mess! There are two locations, Yellow and Blue Pod. Both are in the ED. Blue Pod is not locked but Yellow Pod is. A lot of the Yellow Pod Staff throw you under the bus or decide that they don’t like you just because. As an Officer, you get ZERO training on handling Behavioral Health Patients and everything you say is wrong according to Staff. Lately they have been placing 3-4 juveniles into a locked unit with convicted sex offenders and management is OK with this because it opens up beds in the ED. • The Process improvement is punitive. The whole point of the I-Care reporting system is to help fix issues within the organization. The Security Department is the only department that seems to think they are above the process. After an I-Care is written (even minor ones) they pull you into the office, ask you about it, and then tell you that “this talk is not bad talk” and they then proceed to tell you everything you did wrong without half the time taking into account your side. • They will throw you under the bus for the sake of the organization before they have your back. For a bunch of Former Police Officer they don’t have your back. You are thrown to the wolves and Managers/Directors can never do wrong. • The Hospital as a whole has become a miserable place to work. All the resources have been diverted to Laconia and Franklin. The hospital is not cleaned, the patients are not receiving appropriate care and EVERY staff member, minus the boys/girls on the Third-Floor are suffering. They like to say this is every hospital, BUT ITS NOT!

job_title: Licensed Nursing Assistant LNA in Laconia, NH

cons: Management needs improvement low salary

job_title: Health Unit Coordinator (HUC) in Concord, NH
pros: Convenient location that is about it
cons: Awful Hospital to work for. They show no value of your work ethics. Absolutely no flexibility even with family emergency situations. You are just an another body to them. They would rather hire new under qualified bodies who can’t do half the duties than just be respectful and caring to their current employees needs. Also, once you quit even with notice do not expect to ever be hired back even in other departments.

review_title: Once a collegial hospital, now simply dangerous to patients and practice
pros: The salary is fair. The benefits are good for physicians.
cons:
The culture is that RNs know more than physicians. They sincerely believe the "order sets" that haven't been updated in decades are modern medicine. Physicians do NOT get the backup of management if there are RN vs medical staff conflicts within the Hospitalist group.

Medical staff procedures for grieves are ignored and management will do what they please. 

Subspecialist backup is a fantasy. They refuse to come in for emergencies endangering patients and your license. 

Quite frankly, I can't think of a worse place to work as a Hospitalist.

pros:

pros: Generally good program and I have felt very supported during my time here. Strengths include global health, emergency and hospital medicine, complex chronic disease management.
cons: Areas for improvement include obstetrics, gynecology, and substance use treatment. Additionally, the clinic is very forward thinking and openly working on equity and inclusion issues, whereas the associated hospital system is slow to change.

They'll fire you over an emergency surgery that is out of your control and say it's due to scheduling inconvenience and your "attendance" after they're the ones that tell you not to go into numerous shifts.

job_title: Certified Medical Assistant in Concord, NH
pros: zero pros for this place
cons: all cons for this place

review_title: I would return, but I would be selective in my manager & attitude of the department
pros:
Healthy food options, friendly & supportive physicians & surgeons, loved working with the patients. They were there to be helped, and it was a blessing to be a part of that.
I have to admit, there were a few RN's that were fabulous to work with. They "helped" when necessary the LNA's vs. treating them like they were servants with no value (yes, some RN's mistreated LNA's)
cons:
Too much micro-managing to the point where patient care was impaired, Due to needing to "stay within budget" training was declined for LNA's. Poor attitude throughout, lack of co-operation between departments, HR was lacking in supporting employees.
Even as a patient, employees are unhappy.

pros: The organization is full of great providers
cons: They are going through a lot of changes, not convinced it's for the better

job_title: Food Service Worker in Concord, NH
pros: No pros to speak of or scrape from the bottom of the barrel.
cons: It's really interesting to me how they go about finding and hiring managers. I worked at CRHC from 2003 to 2004 when I was 19. I was insulted, berated, and sexual harassed by my manager. I went to HR to discuss the matter, and they said they could not help me, that that was the way this man managed. My only option was to stay longer and transfer departments, so I did. After transferring new manager (who was amazing) unfortunately had to leave for a shoulder injury. When my new manager left HR put my old harassing manager back in charge of me. They then told me that I was not allowed to transfer departments again ultimately forcing me to quit. More recently the manager who harassed me was on the news for not one, but four felonious counts of forcible sexual fondling - not entirely sure what that conviction entails, but it doesn't sound great and validates my story of being harassed. Even more recently this company has hired my old co-worker who slept.with my.manager, which resulted in his divorce and loss of his three children. She now manages in the food service department. SHE SLEEPS WITH MARRIED MEN AND HAS NO MANAGEMENT EXPERIENCE TO SPEAK OF. HOW DID SHE GET THIS JOB?!?!?!

pros: The staff. Most people do a great job and are hard workers.  Most people will go out of their way to help each other or patients.
cons:
The staff.  Some people do nothing and get away with everything!  Management  is awful. Management are untrained staff, who couldn't manage their way out if a paper bag!  When managers are lacking or incompetent,  they are rewarded with promotions.  
Work hard and get no reward. Don't work and get rewarded. 
No employee recognition programs. No incentives to work hard. 
The new CEO is all about the mighty dollar.  Which he gets from his employees by over charging for their medical care!  Self funded insurance company. Funded by CH employees!  
This USED to be a great place to work!  Now its not, since our old CEO resigned!

pros:
As a company, I have found that there are very fair with their employees.  For the most part we have been encouraged to speak to our supervisors, our higher if needed.  I have always felt that I was heard, whether or not a solution could be rendered.  

They provide a good working atmosphere.   The room for advancement is not always available due to the lack of turn over, nor new positions opened.

In my 10+ years with the company my pay has increased while similar facilities have not been as fortunate, and our benefits have remained very good.
cons:
While the above is a positive it can be a downfall.  

With a large facilities you can become a number, as with as my place with thousands of employees.

pros: Seems that most people like their positions. I think depends on where and who you work for.. and if the manager likes you.
cons: Floors lack management. No one wants to work on the 3rd or 5th floor. They are understaffed and management is lacking. 4th floor is truly dirty... How can management not see the need for more staff and the filth. 6 floor is run by a bias manager who favors certain people and sides..

review_title: CH: Where No Two Days are the Same, and the Future is Near!
job_title: Assistant to the Director in Concord, NH
pros: Flexibility, great work-life balance, understanding and accommodating staff, access to courses and workshops, management working diligently to get you/your team/entire organization to a better place. When you work for Concord Hospital, you are treated like a human being, not a number.
cons: None personally but did hear the following from other employees: underdeveloped technology in some departments, lack of communication between floors/departments, high turnover rate or understaffed shifts.

pros: Love being around people and done cleaning but I need a new job doing.
cons: A am a team player and the team player means that you work with other people and willing to get right in and help people that need help and they shouldn't have to ask you to help me out. Most of the time people should help and work with all other people together this is team work!

job_title: Critical Care RN in Concord, NH
pros: Work with amazing people. Management is supportive. Education is amazing, relevant and paid for! Physicians I work with treat me like I make a difference and involve me in the plan for my patients. They also listen to the nurses when something is wrong.
cons:
Pay is not comparable to hospitals within 30 min radius, especially if you start as a new grad nurse. 
It would be nice if they increased the tuition reimbursement.
A float pool is needed at this hospital
Nurses working in critical care areas, should be paid more than floor nurses because they are required to have advanced certifications as well as are required to be on call.

pros:
Positive and nurturing environment.  Everyone is treated like family here. 
Excellent physician-nurse relationships. 
Focus is highly emphasized on quality patient care and safety. 
The organization and management care about their employees.
cons:
No salary market adjustment for over five years. 
Inadequate RN salaries for nurses who have worked within the organization or have RN experience of  <6 years.  Many hospitals, nursing homes, and VNA organizations in the surrounding area have higher starting rates for new grad nurses. 
Average yearly compensation for nurses is 2-3%. 
Not compensated for obtaining bachelor's degree in nursing.  It would be nice at least to have appropriate credentials on name tags.

review_title: Overall a decent place to work, but limited opportunity for advancement at 40-60% of market salary

cons: Limited opportunity for advancement.   Salary is not competetive at 40-60% of market.
